./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Anyone Can build an Awesome Website
Using resources like Bootstrap and Salesforce Lightning Design System (SLDS) anyone can write a modern web app or website for any smart device or desktop.
In this hands-on workshop you will start with the basics of HTML and CSS and quickly create your first responsive web site, gaining an understanding of responsive design principles along the way.
You can apply the lessons learned to any websites or Lightning Components you create.

Pre-requisites
This website assumes no knowledge of writing a website or the any of the principles of responsive design.
All you will need is a fairly modern browser (Chrome, Firefox, etc.) and a text editor.  You can use any editor you like, however you may find one of the following useful

Atom editor
Sublime Text
Emacs or Spacemacs

Images for the Workshop
All the images used in the workshop can be downloaded as a zip file
Random images just for fun
Poh stairs

Poh denied food animated gif

Poh Epic reaction

Poh top of stairs

overview/.title: Overview of web technology
overview/.body:
Overview of web technology
The idea of Web pages has been around since the early 1990's and whilst there have been many additions, the basic principles are still the same.
Three parts to a web page
Any web pages is made up of three parts

Content
Structure
Style

No matter how simple or complicated a website it, it always has these three things.
Content
Content is the easiest part of your web page to understand, as it the visible part of the web page.  All the text on the page, the images, video or even sounds are all the content of your web page.
If this is your web page, then its the creative part of building the web page.  Its where you convey your thoughts and ideas with words, images and sound.
When you are looking at someone else's page, the content is the part you are interested in viewing (unless you want to see how someone build a specific page).

Example: When I go to the BBC website, I want to go and find the latest news.  The news itself is the content of that website.

Structure
The structure of your web page tells the browser how to organise the content.  So when we write the content of our web page we are able to define the layout of that content when its viewed.
Using Hypertext Markup Language, HTML for short, you can use tags to define structure for the various parts of your content.  Using a &lt;h1&gt; tag you could indicate which part of your content is a heading, or using a &lt;p&gt; tag you could identify things as a paragraph.
There are a great many tags you can use and you sholdnt try learn them all at once.
Style
When you create content, it is hopefully of interest to others.  One way to make the content more applealing is to make that content visually appealing.
The structure can give you a good layout of your content, applying styles can make that page visually stunning and more appealing to the viewer.
Common examples of styles you apply to your content include:

using a specific font family, different font sizes for different parts of your content

Whilst style can be added all within the HTML tags you use to create the structure, most of the style is now defined using Cascading Stylesheets.

TOD: Insert picture of a visually stunning web page.

overview/hypertext-markup-language.html.title: Hypertext Markup Language
overview/hypertext-markup-language.html.body:
Hypertext Markup Language
HTML (Hypertext Markup Language) is the set of markup symbols or codes inserted in a file intended for display on a World Wide Web browser page. The markup tells the Web browser how to display a Web page's words and images for the user.


What is HTML (Hypertext Markup Language)?

overview/cascading-stylesheets.html.title: Cascading Stylesheets
overview/cascading-stylesheets.html.body:
Cascading Stylesheets
Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) is a style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in a markup language.

overview/responsive-design.html.title: Responsive Design Overview
overview/responsive-design.html.body:
Responsive Design
Responsive design is a way to create websites so they display the most appropriate layout of you content, depending on which size device you view it upon.
This means that you only need to build one version of your website, saving time and maintenance costs.  It also allows you to present content and menus in the most appropriate form for the size of the device.
Here is a simple example of a page changing shape as the size of the browser window changes.  You can see how different parts of the layout move around and underneath each other.  Also the way the menu is presented changes with respect to the size of the window.


Examples
The website for this workshop is responsive, try reducing the size of the browser window and see what happens.
Other examples of responsive websites:

https://www.lightningdesignsystem.com
http://getbootstrap.com
https://developer.salesforce.com
https://trailhead.salesforce.com
http://hackthetower.co.uk

There are many resources about responsive design freely available on the Internet, for example 9 Gifs that explain responsive design brilliantly.
Responsive Design is not Adaptive Design
The Adaptive approach means creatiing several versions of the same design, but for different sizes of devices.  Although this can be used to create a highly targeted result for a device, this does require additional work for each device.  Due to the explosion in devices of all shapes and sizes (and screen resolutions), this approach quickly became untenable.
  
  
  
    To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that
    supports HTML5 video

responsive-design/grid-system.html.title: Grid System
responsive-design/grid-system.html.body:
The Grid System
The Grid system is used to control how your content is laid out with respect to responsive design.
Each row of the grid is composed of columns.  You can divide your content up into 2 or more columns per row, up to a total of 12.

The size of columns on a row can be different, so you could have two columns that take up 50% of the screen and a third column that takes up the other 50%.
To do this you would make the first two columns be 3 grid columns wide, the third column would be 6 grids columns wide.  This gives a total of 12.

simple-web-page/.title: Create a simple web page

simple-web-page/structure-of-html-page.h.title: Structure of an html page
simple-web-page/structure-of-html-page.h.body:
Structure of an html page
There is a standard for web pages which is managed by an organisation called W3.org
The basic structure of any web pages is quite simple and made up from three tags

html
head
body

A tag being a name or character surrounded by angle brackets, < >, that indicates semantic meaning about the content.  Tags come in pairs, indicating which part of the content you are affecting.
Tags
Tags specify the types of things in the HTML language, such as paragraphs, images, headings, etc.
The names of tags are surrounded by angle brackets, < >
Most tags are written as pairs, surrounding the content for which they define.  The opening tag is of the form  and the closing tag has a forward slash as in </name>.
For example:
<html>
Content of your web page
</html>


Hint For simplicity, when referring to tags outside of specific examples, the names will be used without the angle bracketsg

simple-web-page/html.html.title: Html

simple-web-page/head.html.title: Head

simple-web-page/body.html.title: Body

simple-web-page/paragraph.html.title: Paragraph

simple-web-page/images.html.title: Images
simple-web-page/images.html.body:
Images
In HTML, images are defined with the img tag.
The img tag is empty in that it does not surround any text and does not have a closing tag.  The img tag can contain attributes about the image, such as size and if the image has a border.
The src attribute specifies the URL (web address) of the image:
<img src="url" alt="some_text"> 

<img src="url" alt="some_text" style="width:width;height:height;">


Hint The img tag is one of the few tags that does not have a closing part to the tag.  All the information is contained within the tag itself.
Image styles can also be defined in a stylesheet (see stylesheets section)

Alternative Text for screen readers
By adding an alternative text description of the image, you are supporting the experience for those usingtext to speech tools such as a screen reader.
A screen reader is a software program that reads the HTML code, converts the text, and allows the user to listen to the content. Screen readers are useful for people who are blind, visually impaired, or learning disabled.
Please consider using the alternative text description for all your images.
Image Size - Width and Height
You can use the style attribute to specify the width and height of an image.
The values are specified in pixels (use px after the value):
<img src="html5.gif" alt="HTML5 Icon" style="width:128px;height:128px;">

Images in Another Folder
If not specified, the browser expects to find the image in the same folder as the web page.
However, it is common to store images in a sub-folder. You must then include the folder name in the src attribute:
<img src="/images/html5.gif" alt="HTML5 Icon" style="width:128px;height:128px;">

Images on Another Website
Some web sites store their images on image servers.
Actually, you can access images from any web address in the world:
<img src="http://www.w3schools.com/images/w3schools_green.jpg" alt="W3Schools.com">

simple-web-page/hyperlink.html.title: Hyperlink
simple-web-page/hyperlink.html.body:
HTML links - Hyperlinks
The name HyperText Markup Language (HTML) refers in part to the ability to include links in your page to other areas of the page, other pages in the website or even other pages out on the Internet.
HTML links are hyperlinks and are defined using the anchor tag, a.
The anchor tag also has a type of link, such as html to use web addresses.
You can click on a link and jump to another document.
When you move the mouse over a link, the mouse arrow will turn into a little hand.
link text
Visit our HTML tutorial
The href attribute specifies the destination address (http://www.w3schools.com/html/) of the link.
The link text is the visible text shows in the web page.  Clicking on the link text will send you to the specified address.
Local Links
The example above used a web address, officially referred to as a Universal Resource Location (URL).
A local link is a link to a different file in the same web site.  This link is specified with just the name of the file.
Example
my images
HTML Link Colors
The text of the link will appear in a different colour, as follows:

An unvisited link is underlined and blue
A visited link is underlined and purple
An active link is underlined and red

You can change the default colors, by using styles:
<style>
  a:link    {color:green; background-color:transparent; text-decoration:none}
  a:visited {color:pink; background-color:transparent; text-decoration:none}
  a:hover   {color:red; background-color:transparent; text-decoration:underline}
  a:active  {color:yellow; background-color:transparent; text-decoration:underline}
</style>

HTML Links - The target Attribute
The target attribute specifies where to open the linked document.
The target attribute can have one of the following values:

_blank - Opens the linked document in a new window or tab
_self - Opens the linked document in the same window/tab as it was clicked (this is default)
_parent - Opens the linked document in the parent frame
_top - Opens the linked document in the full body of the window
framename - Opens the linked document in a named frame

This example will open the linked document in a new browser window/tab:
<a href="http://www.w3schools.com/" target="_blank">Visit W3Schools!</a>

HTML Links - Image as Link
An image can also be turned into a link as well.  This is useful if you want to represent a topic or section of your website visually, rather than with just text.
<a href="happy-smiley-people.html">
  <img src="smiley.gif" alt="Happy people in our world" style="border:0;">
</a>

bootstrap/.title: Bootstrap
bootstrap/.body:
Bootstrap
Bootstrap is a library containing styles, themes and Javascript (jQuery) that makes it easier to create a responsive and dynamic website.
Bootstrap is arguably the most popular HTML, CSS, and JS framework for developing responsive, mobile first projects on the web.  Bootstrap has helped raise the bar of website design so that most websites at least look pretty good and are fairly responsive.



Hint Once you have seen a few Bootstrap powered websites it does become easy to spot them, so consider Bootstrap the start of your journey into responsive design.

bootstrap/get-bootstrap.html.title: Get Bootstrap

bootstrap/offline-development.html.title: Offline Development
bootstrap/offline-development.html.body:
Offline development with Bootstrap
If you are working offline (eg. travelling) you can also download Bootstrap.
Selecting the Download Bootstrap button will prompt you to save a .zip file on your computer

This .zip file should be copied to the same directory that contains your index.html file.
Or alternatively you can create a new sub-directory called css in the same directory as your index.html file.

If you want to customise Bootstrap, then you would download the Bootstrap source code.  However if you just want to over-ride some of the styles, you can create your own styles.css and include that after bootstrap in the &lt;head&gt; section of your page.

bootstrap/examples.html.title: Examples
bootstrap/examples.html.body:
Bootstrap Examples
There are a number of examples you can use as starting points when creating a new website with Bootstrap

Custom Components

design-our-page/.title: Design our page
design-our-page/.body:
Design our web page
Before we start writing our responsive web page, lets draw out the overall design.
By drawing out the design of the page, you can identify the different sections of content you have and how you may want to group them and then lay them out on the web page.
Here is an example design where we have added visible boxes to show the sections of content and how we think they should be grouped.  These visible boxes on the design will probably not be on the website itself (unless it adds to the design experience).

make-page-responsive/.title: Make our page responsive
make-page-responsive/.body:
Make our Web Page responsive
To build our design we are going to carry out a number of steps:

Add Bootstrap styles, theme and Javascript to our index.html file
Add a Jumbotron section for Poh's summary
Add an experiences section
Add a qualifications section with multiple qualifications on a row
Add a friends & Where Am I section on the same row
Add a feed from Spottify
Add a feed from Twitter

make-page-responsive/top-nav-bar.html.title: Top Nav Bar menu
make-page-responsive/top-nav-bar.html.body:
Top Nav Bar

Fixme This section is work in progress, sorry

If you have multiple pages on your website or lots of different sections all on one page, you may want to include a menu on your page to help people jump to specific parts of your page or site.
Types of Nav bar
You can have a navbar that just appears at the top of the page and disappears off the top when you scroll the web page.
You can also have a navbar that stays at the top of the web page even when you scroll.

where-next/.title: Where Next
where-next/.body:
